qas.question: What has copper been used for since ancient times?
In recent times what is one interior use copper been expanded to include?
What is an important benefit to using copper as an architectural material?
How long has copper been used in building construction?
What is the benefit to using copper for things such as counter tops and hand rails?
What has copper been avoided as since ancient times?
What is one interior use copper has been forbidden to include?
What is an important danger to using copper as an architectural material?
How long has copper been banned in building construction?
What is the danger to using copper for things such as counter tops and hand rails?

context: Copper has been used since ancient times as a durable, corrosion resistant, and weatherproof <a0_0><b5_0>architectural material<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Roofs, flashings, rain gutters, downspouts, domes, spires, vaults, and doors have been made from copper for <a3_0><b8_0>hundreds or thousands of years<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Copper's architectural use has been expanded in modern times to include interior and exterior wall cladding, building expansion joints, radio frequency shielding, and <a1_0><a4_0><b6_0><b9_0>antimicrobial<b9_0/><a4_0/> indoor products<b6_0/><a1_0/>, such as attractive handrails, bathroom fixtures, and counter tops. Some of copper's other important benefits as an architectural material include its <a2_0><b7_0>low thermal movement<b7_0/><a2_0/>, light weight, lightning protection, and its recyclability.
